newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia Yield Spreads - Renew tightening to U.S.
newsitem.headline: Australia Yield Spreads - Renew tightening to U.S.

text.p: The long end of the Australian bond yield curve renewed its spread compression to the U.S. with some analysts still looking at the prospect of parity down the track.

"Since breaking +65 (basis points) term support and the registering of multi year new lows in this spread...plenty of scope for the AUD curve to move onto parity valuations," said Peter Pontikis, technical strategist at Westpac in a report.
The Australian/U.S. 10-year spread slid to around 35 basis points last Thursday, its lowest level since the early 1980s, following a weaker than expected employment report.
While it has given up some ground in the past couple of days it was back testing 40 b.p. today, and where clear break would open the way for a move towards a major barrier at 25 b.p.
The next significant move could occur next week if next week's data confirms the forecast benign outcome for second quarter inflation, along with an expected acceptable level of wages growth.
A technical bounce after the market had initially shown nervousness over the sustained slide in the Australian dollar prompted today's spread tightening at the long-end.
Meanwhile, New Zealand bonds were under pressure once again as the market struggled to keep monetary conditions near desired levels as the N.Z. dollar fell.
